questions.text: When performing a replantation of an amputated finger, which of the following is the correct order of surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: Bone, Artery, Extensor, Flexor, Nerve, Vein

options.label: B
options.text: Artery, Bone, Vein, Extensor, Flexor, Nerve

options.label: C
options.text: Artery, Bone, Extensor, Flexor, Vein, Nerve

options.label: D
options.text: Bone, Extensor, Flexor, Artery, Nerve, Vein

questions.correct_answer: D. Bone, Extensor, Flexor, Artery, Nerve, Vein
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bone, Extensor, Flexor, Artery, Nerve, Vein This is a well-known order. A useful way of remembering it is to BE a FAN of V. A stable platform is needed for reconstruction. Then the deep structures must be repaired before the delicate arterial and nerve repairs. Or also remembered as BE FAN of VS – Bone, extensor tendon, flexor tendon, arteries, nerves, veins , and skin

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Extensors are second to be replanted, not artery Option: B. Bone is the first to be replanted, not the artery Option: C. Bone is the first to be replanted, not the artery

questions.text: A construction worker sustains traumatic amputations to the thumb and index finger of his dominant hand while using a table saw. Replantation is performed. What is the most common cause of the replanted digits' early (within 12 hours) failure?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Arterial thrombosis+ Arterial thrombosis is the most common cause of early failure, Occurs due to persistent vasospasm. INTRAOSSEOUS BLOOD SUPPLY SITE OF THROMBOSIS An adequate anticoagulation cover is given to overcome failure due to thrombosis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Venous congestion is one of the early complications of failure but not the most common cause of the replanted digits' early (within 12 hours) failure. Elevation of a limb can help reduce venous congestion CEAP CLASSIFICATION Option: C. Infection is an early complication of replantation but not the most common cause of the replanted digits' early (within 12 hours) failure. It is to be noted that infection is more common in upper extremity replantation which develops as a result of myonecrosis Option: D. Irreversible nerve damage is a long-term complication associated with replantation

questions.text: All the following are advantages of the Jaipur foot over the conventional SACH foot except which of the following??

options.label: A
options.text: The appearance of the Jaipur foot is that of a normal foot

options.label: B
options.text: It is suitable for barefoot walking

options.label: C
options.text: Allows movement at forefoot and midfoot

questions.correct_answer: D. Jaipur foot is electrically operated
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Jaipur foot is electrically operated Jaipur's foot has a rubber core, wooden block, and vulcanized rubber coating. This permits a combination of stiffness and pliability. Different types of foot prostheses are: Jaipur foot Solid ankle cushion heel (SACH) Stationary attachment flexible endoskeleton(SAFE), similar to Jaipur foot.

questions.text: A 40 years old blind patient from a low socioeconomic background suffered severe trauma to his upper limbs. The following procedure was performed. What is the performed amputation named?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Krukenberg's amputation The given image is of Krukenberg’s amputation . In this procedure, the radius and ulna are split to make a pincer mechanism. It has been recommended in blind patients with bilateral below-elbow amputation or in patients who can’t afford expensive prostheses.

Level of amputation Forequarter amputation: Entire upper extremity in the interval b/w scapula and chest wall is removed. Krukenberg amputation: For blind patients; it converts the forearm to forecep. Mid-foot amputations: Lisfranc→ TMT Joint Chopart→ Mid- tarsal joint

questions.text: Upon meeting with an accident; the patient suffered an injury to the foot. On examination, you find that it's a crush injury of the foot. Following the ATLS protocol, you stabilize the hemodynamics of the patient and inform your consultant. The consultant on observing the state of injury decides to do a below knee amputation. How should the nerves be sectioned whenever performing amputation?

options.label: A
options.text: Nerves should be pulled distally and then cut with a sharp knife

options.label: B
options.text: Nerves should be identified and then cut with electrocautery\

options.label: C
options.text: Nerves should be removed distally and then cut with scissors

questions.correct_answer: A. Nerves should be pulled distally and then cut with a sharp knife
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nerves should be pulled distally and then cut with a sharp knife Nerves are gently pulled distally into the wound, and divided with a sharp knife so that the cut end retracts well proximal to the level of bone section. Large nerves such as the sciatic nerve contain relatively large vessels and should be ligated before they are divided. Major blood vessels should be isolated.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Yes definitely the nerve needs to be identified but what is more important afterward is that it is to be pulled distally and then sectioned with a sharp knife. Option: C. Nerves should be preferably sectioned with a sharp knife rather than any other surgical instrument. Option: D. Ruled out since A is the answer.

questions.text: A 66-year-old male patient with a gangrenous foot secondary to peripheral vascular disease is planned for foot amputation. You have been assigned this case and must assist your operation theatre consultant. On the preoperative evaluation of the patient, your consultant decides to test your knowledge of the principles of amputation. He asks you whether a tourniQuet should be used in this patient. What should be your answer and why?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, it will minimize the blood loss

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, it will help in saving operative time

options.label: C
options.text: Depending on the discretion of the surgeon

options.label: D
options.text: No, it is contraindicated in ischaemic limbs

questions.correct_answer: D. No, it is contraindicated in ischaemic limbs
questions.explanation:
Solution:

No, it is contraindicated in ischaemic limbs Tourniquet use is contraindicated in patients with ischaemic limbs who are planned for amputation as its application may further compromise the blood flow to the limb. Limbs with severe infection, patients with poor cardiac reserve, and traumatized limbs are relative contraindications to tourniquet use

Highyeild:

Treatment of acute limb ischemia A Once you diagnose "Immediate anticoagulation with heparin to avoid clot propagation • Appropriate analgesia • Simple measures to improve existing perfusion: • Keep the foot dependant • Avoid pressure over the heel • Avoid extremes of temperature • Maximum tissue oxygenation (oxygen inhalation) • Correct hypotension • Start treatment of other associated cardiac conditions (CHF, AF)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Use of a tourniquet is highly desirable in amputations except in the case of an ischaemic limb. Option: B. Use of a tourniquet may help in reducing operative time but its use is contraindicated in patients with ischaemic limbs Option: C. Use of a tourniquet is highly desirable in amputations except in the case of an ischaemic limb.

The plan has also been made for amputation of the injured foot and the amputation has been done. What is the most common cause of amputations?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Peripheral vascular disease Peripheral vascular disease is the most common cause of amputations. Amputations are defined as the removal of a limb through a part of the Disarticulation is the removal of the limb through the joint .
